Award.AwardTitle: Topological Insulator Hybrid Structures for Novel Optoelectronic Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to exploit unique advantages of topological insulator based structures for optoelectronic applications. Specifically, the strong magnetoelectric interaction at the topological insulator-magnetic material interface and subsequent band engineering is the key focus as they can facilitate tailored response to an optical signal, offering an ideal environment for previously unattainable performances such as extreme sensitivity detection. The combined theoretical and experimental effort aims to achieve synthesis, fabrication, and analysis of novel topological insulator materials and layered heterostructures as well as demonstration of superior device functionalities.
Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit is that the investigation presents a basis for realizable topological insulator based devices beyond the current state-of-the art. Through the paradigm of domain matching epitaxy, the effort pursues synthesis of epitaxial topological insulator/ferromagnetic insulator hybrid structures with atomistic uniformity at the interface on a silicon compatible platform. The target materials include both Bi2Se3 and emerging cubic candidates such as inverse perovskite Sr3SnO and half-Heusler LuPtSb. The investigation also develops fundamental theoretical understanding of topological insulator properties and photo-response characteristics of various terahertz detector designs.
Broader Impacts: The broader impacts are the education/training of graduate and undergraduate students in addition to advanced device development with technological importance. Of particular significance is participation and recruiting of minority students by fostering strong ties to local historically black colleges and universities. The outreach is also pursued through ASM Materials Camp, a successful annual summer event for high school students, as well as the online distance education network.
This project is jointly funded by the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices Program (EPMD) in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title: Topological Insulator Hybrid Structures for Novel Optoelectronic Applications

PIs: Ki Wook Kim and Jagdish Narayan, North Carolina State University

Funding Agency: National Science Foundation

The formation of epitaxial NV nanonamonds in discrete structures (in the form of triangles, squares, hexagons, rings) and large-area single-crystal films with deterministic placement will lead to novel atomic sensors, biomarkers and quantum computers operating at room temperature. These NV structures can lead to quantum computing, sensing and safe data transmission, including the formation of time crystals under periodic nonequilibrium photonic, electronic and thermal excitations.

Currently, NV (color-center) nanodiamonds are synthesized by detonation, ball milling, e- and ion irradiation. Detonation suffers from impurity contamination and the presence of diamond-like-carbon near the surface. Ball milling creates defects as well as loss of N, while e- and ion irradiations at high temperatures leave damage and create undesirable defects. In addition, e- irradiations take days (>10) of processing at high temperatures, resulting in formation of undesired N2V, V2N, and N+ defects with net spins, and thus rendering these methods impractical for device fabrication. In the case of CVD-based methods, nanodiamonds are often embedded in amorphous carbon where color-center density is limited due to solid solubility limit.

Our transformative approach to create NV diamond crystals by nanosecond laser melting and quenching from super undercooled state in the form of epitaxial nanodots, nanoneedles, and large-area single-crystal thin films. Self-assembly of these structures is controlled from triangle, square, hexagon to rings, where size and separation can be controlled precisely to study their interaction and entanglement. Control of position and orientation of color-centers is attained by our transformative method, which is well beyond the capabilities of the current methods. These high-quality NV nanodiamonds are placed on a substrate with all having <111> orientation with controlled spacing needed for the entanglement for quantum computing and other applications. We have used quantitative atomic resolution imaging, EELS and CL spectroscopy to study NV quantum efficiency, life-time and second-order correlation function (g2(t)) of emitted photons and establish detailed characterization and structure-property correlations. Control of position and orientation of color-centers is attained by our transformative method, which is well beyond the capabilities of the current methods.
